channel.title: World
channel.description: The Washington Post World section provides information and analysis of breaking world news stories. In addition to our world news and video, Post World News offers discussions and blogs on major international news and economic issues.

item.title: Ukraine live briefing: Schumer, McConnell urge release of journalist; no consular access for reporter
item.dc:creator: Andrew Jeong
item.description: The White House said U.S. officials have not been granted consular access to Evan Gershkovich, the Wall Street Journal reporter detained in Russia.

item.title: Live updates: Violence flares in Israel amid tension along Lebanon border
item.dc:creator: Louisa Loveluck
item.description: One person was killed and five others injured in what Israeli authorities described as a terrorist attack in Tel Aviv on Friday evening.

item.title: Two Israeli sisters killed in West Bank shooting as violence escalates
item.dc:creator: Claire Parker
item.description: The attack Friday, which Palestinian militant group Hamas celebrated, added to tensions as Israel and Palestinian militants exchanged rocket fire.

item.title: Ukraine live briefing: Schumer, McConnell urge release of journalist; no consular access for reporter
item.dc:creator: Andrew Jeong
item.description: The White House said U.S. officials have not been granted consular access to Evan Gershkovich, the Wall Street Journal reporter detained in Russia.

item.title: Live updates: Violence flares in Israel amid tension along Lebanon border
item.dc:creator: Louisa Loveluck
item.description: One person was killed and five others injured in what Israeli authorities described as a terrorist attack in Tel Aviv on Friday evening.

item.title: Two Israeli sisters killed in West Bank shooting as violence escalates
item.dc:creator: Claire Parker
item.description: The attack Friday, which Palestinian militant group Hamas celebrated, added to tensions as Israel and Palestinian militants exchanged rocket fire.

item.title: Violence spreads to West Bank, Tel Aviv as threat of wider conflict fades
item.dc:creator: Louisa Loveluck
item.description: A nervous calm settled over Jerusalem Friday after a day of rocket fire and Israeli airstrikes, but a deadly shooting attack in the West Bank risked new escalation.

item.title: The Israeli-Palestinian conflict: A chronology
item.dc:creator: Brian Murphy
item.description: Decades of conflict, tensions and the occasional hope for peace.

item.title: French winegrowers light candles to protect vines from spring frost
item.dc:creator: Erin Cunningham
item.description: French winemakers scrambled this week amid subzero temperatures to light thousands of candles and protect their vines from a potentially devastating frost.

item.title: A timeline of recent violence between Israelis and Palestinians
item.dc:creator: Ruby Mellen
item.description: This week's escalation comes in what has been a year of near-daily violence and Israeli raids in the occupied West Bank.

item.title: One soldier killed, one wounded in explosion in western Russia
item.dc:creator: Francesca Ebel
item.description: Amid reports of the strange blast in Bryansk near the Ukrainian border, Russia's Finance Ministry reported a steep drop in energy revenues.

item.title: Why Israeli raids on al-Aqsa Mosque are stoking tensions
item.dc:creator: Claire Parker
item.description: The Temple Mount or al-Aqsa Mosque compound lies at the heart of the struggle between Israelis and Palestinians over Jerusalem. Israeli forces raided the site during Ramadan.

item.title: In Photos: Israel launches strikes on Lebanon and Gaza after rocket barrage
item.dc:creator: Washington Post Staff
item.description: Friday prayers at al-Aqsa Mosque in occupied East Jerusalem began amid high tensions, after Israel carried out airstrikes in Lebanon and the Gaza Strip early Friday and the risk of a wide-scale regional conflict grew.

item.title: Rohingya refugees brave perilous seas to escape camp desperation
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Tan
item.description: At least 348 Rohingya died or went missing last year, the United Nations says, as they turned to smugglers to flee worsening conditions in the sprawling Bangladeshi camps.

item.title: How Poland became the new ‘center of gravity’ in Europe
item.dc:creator: Ishaan Tharoor
item.description: The war in Ukraine has ushered in a kind of geopolitical shift in Europe, away from its traditional anchors in France and Germany. In Central and Eastern Europe, wrote Le Monde columnist Sylvie Kauffmann, “the weight of history is stronger … the traumas are fresher and the return of tragedy is felt more keenly.”

item.title: Israel launches strikes on Lebanon after major rocket barrage
item.dc:creator: Louisa Loveluck
item.description: The Israel Defense Forces said it struck infrastructure belonging to Hamas in southern Lebanon, as tensions continued to rise in the region.

item.title: New Indian textbooks purged of nation’s Muslim history
item.dc:creator: Anumita Kaur
item.description: The Taj Mahal is iconic. But not all Indian students will be taught who built it.

item.title: Ukraine live briefing: Macron urges Xi to help end war; U.S. demands access to reporter jailed in Russia
item.dc:creator: Niha Masih
item.description: Efforts by U.S. diplomats to gain access to Wall Street Journal reporter Evan Gershkovich remain unsuccessful.

item.title: Russian court delays custody decision for girl who made antiwar drawing
item.dc:creator: Francesca Ebel
item.description: The court said it could not make a decision because it did not know the whereabouts of her father, Alexei Moskalyov, who was reportedly detained in Belarus after fleeing house arrest in Russia.

item.title: Protesters storm BlackRock building, clash with police over France’s pension reform
item.dc:creator: Claire Parker
item.description: Strikes and protests over pension reform continued to block streets and key services in France, though the number of participants appeared to be dwindling.

item.title: Former Italian leader Silvio Berlusconi in treatment for leukemia
item.dc:creator: Sammy Westfall
item.description: The former prime minister is in intensive care for a lung infection, and has been in treatment for leukemia "for some time," his doctors said in a statement.

item.title: China’s military aims to launch 13,000 satellites to rival Elon Musk’s Starlink
item.dc:creator: Cate Cadell
item.description: In the race for low-earth orbit dominance, Beijing is years behind SpaceX and worried about the national security threat.

item.title: How progressive Denmark became the face of the anti-migration left
item.dc:creator: Emily Rauhala
item.description: Danish authorities are threatening settled refugees with deportation and pushing for overseas processing centers. It may be a sign of what's to come in Europe.

item.title: Nailed to a cross, Filipino prays for Ukraine war to end
item.dc:creator: Jim Gomez | AP
item.description: Eight Filipinos have been nailed to crosses to reenact Jesus Christ’s suffering in a bloody Good Friday tradition

item.title: In Nicaragua, Holy Week celebrations limited by government
item.dc:creator: Gabriela Selser | AP
item.description: Roman Catholics in Nicaragua have had to hold traditional “Stations of the Cross” and other Holy Week processions on church grounds or inside the churches amid a ban on public demonstrations

item.title: 2 men shot to death near beach in Mexican resort of Acapulco
item.dc:creator: Associated Press
item.description: Two men who were apparently Mexican tourists have been shot dead and a woman wounded not far from the beach in Mexico’s once-glamorous resort of Acapulco

item.title: Chains and pains: How one Mexican town celebrates Holy Week
item.dc:creator: Megan Janetsky | AP
item.description: Barefoot, half naked and blindfolded, throngs of middle aged men groan as they drag their bodies along the blazing cobblestone streets of the Mexican town of Atlixco

item.title: Attacks in Israel, West Bank kill 3 in worsening violence
item.dc:creator: Isabel Debre | AP
item.description: Israeli officials say Palestinian assailants carried out a pair of attacks on Friday, killing three people and wounding at least seven

item.title: Hundreds of thousands still in dark from ice storm in Canada
item.dc:creator: Associated Press
item.description: Hundreds of thousands of people remain without power in eastern Canada two days after a storm left parts of Quebec and Ontario coated in ice, causing tree limbs to break and fall on power lines

item.title: Blast at north Iraqi airport raises tension in Kurdish area
item.dc:creator: Salar Salim and Qassim Abdul-Zahra | AP
item.description: Officials say an explosion has struck next to an international airport in northern Iraq’s semi-autonomous Kurdish region

item.title: 3 killed in Northern Italy after car crashes into farm silo
item.dc:creator: Associated Press
item.description: Three people were killed at a farm in Northern Italy when their car crashed into a silo that collapsed and buried their vehicle under an enormous mound of chicken feed

item.title: Life sentences in Congo for killing of Italian ambassador
item.dc:creator: Jean-Yves Kamale | AP
item.description: Six men in Congo were sentenced to life in prison on Friday for the murder of Italy’s ambassador and two others

item.title: Paul Cattermole of UK pop group S Club 7 dies at 46
item.dc:creator: Associated Press
item.description: Paul Cattermole, a member of early-2000s British pop group S Club 7, has died at the age of 46
